items.title: Thank you for your time!
items.content: I've received your responses. If you found this study interesting or enjoyable, I'd really appreciate your help in sharing it with homeschoolers and other students you know—maybe you have a sibling beside you who is old enough to take it. To see how well you stacked up against others in the creativity test, or read more about the methods used to create this study, press "Submit".

What subjects do you study online or on a screen, at least partially?

Choose as many as you like or type an option that's not listed here.

items.label: In the past week, on average, approximately how much time PER DAY did you spend for non-education-related activities on a screen?
items.help: e.g. social media, internet browsing, gaming

items.content: For the questions below, answer with what you have used in the past week or so.

What platforms do you use for your learning?

You can add an option if it's not here.
What apps do you use for your learning?

messageHandlers.title: tomselectize

items.title: Hello!
items.content: I'm Elijah, a 12th-grade homeschooled student who's curious about how students learn online and how this affects their creativity.

8.content:

Rank your choices

Check the top two answers you think were the most creative.

messageHandlers.title: ranking

8.title: Ranking

items.content: When I say "e-learning," I'm referring to any learning that happens using a screen. This study aims to find the correlation between time spent e-learning and divergent thinking. If you want to see the results of this research or you're interested in making something like this, I'll be providing access and explanations at the end of this survey.
items.title: What is this survey about?

items.content: As you fill in these next few questions, there won't always be a "go back" button, so try to be as accurate as possible.

18.title: Time

items.title: Divergent Thinking and E-Learning
items.content: This study was created with Lab.JS, since I found conventional survey software insufficient for the design of the interactivity I required. About your creativity scores—I don't have them just yet, because they'll have to be stacked up against other respondents and assessed by a few people first, but if you shared your email earlier, I'll send them to you soon.

As promised, you'll be able to read my practical free website creation guide. Read it

If you've got time to do even more of this survey, I've got a little bonus section. Just hit Continue

items.title: Part 2: The Creativity Test
items.content: Thank you for filling that out. For this next part, you'll play a game where you'll be prompted with the names of a few common items. Your goal will be to write as many possible alternative or unusual uses for that item as you can in two minutes, then select the best of your ideas. Try to be as creative as possible.

22.content:
Your study schedule

What does a study schedule on an average day look like for you?

Highlight the hours that you typically use for studying below by dragging or tapping. You can select and deselect multiple blocks.

messageHandlers.title: studytime

22.title: Study Time

23.title: Bonus Guide
23.content:
The Fully Free Web Creation Guide

The tools listed here can be used for any website, not just research studies

Don't read on if you'd rather play it by the book and cook up a plain old Google Form. I wouldn't want to waste your precious time. Also, if you've got cash to spend on your research, you may not find this list as useful since all but one service are completely free (see if you can spot it).

When creating my study, I wanted to DIY everything so I could have more control over the data I collected and more structural flexibility on a budget of ₱0. In the process of digging for free tools across the internet, I found that the process of selecting them is highly specific to the goal you want to achieve. Keep it in mind as you browse through this guide.

To set up a website like this one, here's a timeline of what I did and options you can choose depending on your needs.

  1. First, I created the study (this website's content) with Lab.JS.

    You can create your content directly, with code, or with a free website builder if you're not looking to create an experiment like this one. If you are, however, then aside from Lab.JS, you could look into PsyToolkit, PsychoPy, or jsPsych.

  2. I put the study online with Netlify which is a free platform for static websites (i.e. plain designs and images, and interaction that doesn't require much of a server to process). If you want a simple way to view your code on a website, you can use their service Netlify Drop.

    Disclaimer: there is a charge for larger-scale projects and websites.

  3. I acquired this domain (elijahmendoza.nom.za) through NomZa, a free domain name provider run by the government of South Africa for personal use—fantastic for me, since it nicely rhymes with my last name. It's also not blocked on Facebook, which I've found to be a problem with other free domain providers.

    For other ways to get free domains, I like EU.ORG which is free for organizations and personal use. It just takes a while to get approved through their manual process. Other decent options that don't work as reliably on social media, but may be worth considering, are Freenom and FreeDNS. If these options don't suit you, you can find more in this list, but be warned: I can't vouch for its credibility.

  4. If you're creating a study, you'll need a place to store your data. I dislike Google Forms for being overused, and it doesn't work for complicated surveys like this one anyway. This one is running on a little rental server box in the cloud.

    Mine was gifted to me gratis, but you can get your own for free on AWS, Google Cloud, or Azure for one year. However, that may be a little advanced for non-programmers. Alternatively, you can get hosting through HelioNet, ByetHost, or x10hosting for free as well, as well as Heroku or Glitch.

    If this is getting a little over your head, then hosting your data yourself may not be a good option for you. Instead, try something like JATOS or Pavlovia, which are designed for putting up studies like this.

I hope you found this helpful. As I mentioned, it's not comprehensive and your needs may differ, especially since I designed this approach around quantitative research. Questions about this list can be directed to my email or through Messenger. If you appreciated this, once again, I'd truly appreciate you sharing it with people you know. Thanks!

24.title: Rick Astley
24.content:
I don't have anything left to ask you—but if you enjoyed this, please send it to as many students as you know.

https://research.elijahmendoza.nom.za

metadata.title: Divergent Thinking and E-Learning
metadata.description: This is a quick test to find out how creative you are with a game. Or, if it suits you better, the list of completely free resources I used to bootstrap this website. I'll just ask a few questions first.
